data.title: Ralph Tavares: Family, Business, and Beaches
data.meta_description: A look back (and forward) at the career of Ralph Tavares, MBI's 2022 Modular Construction Industry Hall of Fame inductee.
data.text:
Even before graduating from the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro in structural engineering, Ralph Tavares had found employment as a project and construction manager for high-rise condominium projects around Rio de Janeiro. One afternoon in 1978, he returned to the company office and found a newly hired trainee named Silvana sitting at his desk. He immediately asked her to marry him. Alas, she said no! (Fortunately, she later changed her mind.)

Both were hired onto the firm after receiving their college degrees. Ralph as an engineer, Silvana as an architect. When the Brazilian economy tanked in 1981, the company received some land as partial payment for the apartment buildings they sold. But they didnât develop anything on it, so Ralph approached them and asked if he could build something on the land with materials they had left over from other projects. âThey loved the idea and they were great clients. Silvana designed the houses, I did the engineering, and we built them. Itâs much more common in Brazil than in the US to do design-build projects.â They built about two dozen single-family homes made with pre-fabricated concrete slabs, clay bricks, and pre-engineered wood roof trusses. âWe quickly decided to fabricate the concrete slabs ourselves, and started a manufacturing business for forming the slabs and firing our own concrete masonry units for the walls,â Tavares says.

Tavares describes himself as an âarmy bratâ growing up, frequently moving from place to place, following his fatherâs work as a high-ranking infantry army officer in the Brazilian military. When he and Silvana moved to the United States in 1987 with their two young children, he was not afraid to continue the habit of moving frequently. Although it was hard for their children at times, Tavares says that they now appreciate the perspective it gave them â they eventually came to feel confident that they could move anywhere and make new friends in a new place.

The Tavares family first lived on the east coast (including in New York and Connecticut all the way south to Florida) before eventually ending up on the west coast, in California â after a brief period in the Midwest. Speaking of when the family lived in Kansas City, Tavares says, âThe drive to Galveston was over ten hours away. I didnât realize until I lived in Kansas how much I loved the ocean.â He used to body surf and play soccer on the beach every day growing up. Now, heâs more likely to be found simply enjoying the fresh air, walking on the beach with Silvana, eating seafood, or lying in the shade with a book. âI like to travel, I love wine, and I enjoy cooking. Iâm not a chef but I can handle a kitchen. My travel destinations are usually places where I can find great food and great wine.â

Growing up, the Tavares kids spent summers working at the family business and enjoyed it. âIt meant my wife and I could keep them close, keep them on a short leash, and keep our eyes on them,â Ralph says with a laugh.

His son, Pedro, initially went to college to study computer graphics and animation. âBut he came back to us and he now has a Masterâs Degree in Real Estate Development for Architects and heâs in the process of getting his architectural license.â His daughter, Mariana, is a business major and worked for a number of different companies before deciding that she wanted to return to help out with the family firm too. âShe said we didnât even have to pay her,â Tavares says, âbut of course we did!â

Tavares says he is a very calm person. âI'm not hard to work with. I give my son and daughter â all my employees â enough rope to hang themselves,â he jokes. âI donât need to point out mistakes, because they can very quickly recognize their own mistakes themselves, which is the best way to avoid repeating them. Weâre all learning every day how to do things better.â He adds that heâs constantly amazed by the number of family businesses among the MBI membership. âWe fit in well and my family greatly enjoys the MBI family environment.â

Tavares believes itâs important to share knowledge and to volunteer for organizations that help improve the industry for everyone. And his knowledge and experience in the industry is extensive. As well as being an engineer, Tavares is also a licensed building inspector and general contractor. A nice side effect of volunteering is that Tavares meets people in the industry who become clients or who refer clients to him. Heâs been on the MBI board in the past, and is currently serving on the board again, and has volunteered for various Task Forces, taught courses, and helped to write regulations. He has been a Trustee of the MBI Educational Foundation for a long time. Recently, he worked with MBI and the International Code Council on the regulations for container-built structures and for two ICC Standards to be inserted in the code.

He's now part of the Task Force developing the Standard for Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing Systems, Energy Efficiency and Water Conservation in Off-Site Construction, to be released in 2023-2024. Even when he didnât have a lot of staff and was working long hours, he helped out. âNow I have a little bit more time, itâs easier to help,â Tavares says.

As well as volunteering with MBI, heâs also been volunteering with the Rotary Club for over twenty years. Every year â except during the pandemic â he and Silvana go to Mexico with a group of volunteers to do things like re-painting a school, repairing their HVAC system, or installing a playground. âIn each school we work on, we organize a clinic for the needy neighborhood. We bring medical and veterinary staff to run the clinic for a few days.â

One of Tavaresâ âsecrets to successâ in business is that his clients are more than clients â theyâre friends. âThey know they can call me and Iâll help them solve whatever problem theyâre having.â His company gets repeat business because they are problem solvers, like a challenge, do good work, and have good relationships. âWe donât do much marketing. Most of our work comes through word-of-mouth and I meet people at the MBI conference every year.â Well, to be honest, heâs missed it twice in two decades â and one of those times was because the date conflicted with his daughterâs wedding.

âItâs also helped our business to have a wide reach. Weâre licensed in almost every state in the US. Recessions donât always hit every region to the same extent at the same time,â Tavares explains. âSo when things are bad in California, they might be OK on the East Coast or vice versa.â

More people are realizing that modular construction is much faster than conventional construction and that itâs high quality. âFor example, hotel chains realize they can open new hotels faster. So even if the price per square foot is the same as conventional construction, they understand the financial benefits of speed â saving on general conditions and generating revenue sooner.â

Tavares says, âIâve been in this industry for over 35 years, and Iâve seen it skyrocket lately. Iâve never seen before the level of interest we have now.â So the demand is there. However, he says persistent problems are labor and training and that the âbuilding codes need to be more friendly to modular construction, and weâre trying to make that happen.â

The only negative thing Tavares has to say about the modular industry is, âIt makes me sad when I see a modular company fail.â He explains that itâs frustrating to see a company have good intentions, hire lots of smart, talented people, get lots of investment money â but not apply that money correctly. âIf they donât understand construction, donât do their homework, and donât get good advice, they fail. And I like everyone in the industry to succeed because it makes all of us stronger.â
